questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension went to work and had a sudden onset of nausea and vomiting. He was taken to the ER, where his exam was notable for slurred speech and dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing on the left side. His gait was normal. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of slurred speech and dysmetria on the left side indicate a lesion in the left cerebellar hemisphere. The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating voluntary movements, including speech and limb movements. Lesions in the cerebellar hemisphere can result in ipsilateral (same side) symptoms, such as the ones seen in this patient.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cerebellar vermis (Option A): Involved in gait and trunk posture; lesion causes truncal ataxia, not limb ataxia.

Right cerebellar hemisphere (Option B): Would produce right-sided symptoms, not left.

Fastigial nucleus (Option D): Lies medially and works with vermis; lesions here affect posture and balance, not isolated limb coordination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with a cerebellar haemorrhage. The patient exhibited an unsteady "drunk-like" gait, and the physician noted that he swayed while entering the examination room. Which region of the cerebellum was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of an unsteady "Drunk-like" gait and swaying suggest that the cerebellar haemorrhage affected the flocculonodular lobe.

The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for coordinating balance and posture, and damage to this region can result in ataxia and unsteady movements.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hemispheres of the anterior lobe (Option A): Primarily control lower limb posture and tone; lesions here cause gait disturbance, but more often with chronic alcoholism (anterior lobe syndrome).

Hemisphere of the posterior lobe (Option B): Involved in skilled voluntary limb movements; lesions cause limb ataxia, not truncal gait issues.

Interposed nuclei (Option C): Include globose and emboliform nuclei; involved in proximal limb coordination, not primarily gait balance.

choices.text: Inability to perform the Tandem-Gait test
Inability to stand without swaying with eyes open
Inability to control the distance, power or speed of a movement
Inability to perform rapid alternating movements with the hands

questions.text: Dysdiadochokinesia refers to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dysdiadokinesia refers to the inability to perform rapid alternating movements with the hands.

This is a classic cerebellar sign indicating a lesion of the lateral hemisphere (cerebrocerebellum), which is responsible for the coordination of fine distal limb movements.

  • This condition is characterised by difficulty in coordinating and executing movements that require rapid and alternating actions, such as rapidly pronating and supinating the hands.
  • It is often seen in neurological disorders such as cerebellar dysfunction or damage.
  • Seen on the same side as the lesion (ipsilateral findings)
  • Movements become slow, irregular, and uncoordinated on testing

Explanation of Other Options:

Tandem-Gait test (Option A): Used to assess truncal ataxia (vermis lesion), not dysdiadochokinesia.

Standing sway (Option B): Seen in Romberg test, more relevant to sensory ataxia, not cerebellar function.

Distance/power/speed (Option C): Refers to dysmetria, not dysdiadochokinesia.

choices.text: Climbing fibres synapse with multiple Purkinje cells, but excite only Golgi cells
Mossy fibres give direct excitatory input to Purkinje cells
Parallel fibres arise from granule cells and excite Purkinje cells
Purkinje cells provide excitatory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cerebellar afferents and their synapses is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Granule cells, excited by mossy fibres, send axons into the molecular layer where they bifurcate into parallel fibres. These parallel fibres form excitatory synapses with the dendritic trees of Purkinje cells.

  • Mossy fibres: Excitatory; synapse with granule cells → parallel fibres → Purkinje cells
  • Climbing fibres: Excitatory; arise from the inferior olivary nucleus, synapse directly with 1-10 Purkinje cells
  • Purkinje cells: Inhibitory output (GABAergic) to deep cerebellar nuclei
  • Golgi cells: Inhibitory interneurons; regulate input to granule cells
  • Deep cerebellar nuclei: Final excitatory output to brainstem/spinal cord (via efferents)

Cerebellar Circuit:

Explanation of Other Options:

Climbing fibres synapse with multiple Purkinje cells, but excite only Golgi cells (Option A): Incorrect; climbing fibres provide strong excitatory input directly to Purkinje cells, not Golgi cells.

Mossy fibres give direct excitatory input to Purkinje cells (Option B): Incorrect; mossy fibres synapse on granule cells, not directly on Purkinje cells.

Purkinje cells provide excitatory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei (Option D): Incorrect; Purkinje cells are inhibitory, releasing GABA to suppress deep cerebellar nuclei activity.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct arrangement of cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The four deep cerebellar nuclei are embedded in the white matter of each cerebellar hemisphere. From lateral to medial, their anatomical arrangement is:

  1. Dentate nucleus - most lateral, largest, crumpled, bag-shaped
  2. Emboliform nucleus - medial to dentate, ovoid shape
  3. Globose nucleus - medial to emboliform, multiple rounded cell groups
  4. Fastigial nucleus - most medial, near midline and roof of 4th ventricle

(Other options are ruled out)

These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and serve as the main cerebellar output stations, projecting to the red nucleus, thalamus, vestibular and reticular nuclei.

questions.text: The MRI report of a patient admitted with gait disturbances is shown below. Phylogenetically, the oldest part of the atrophied structure is associated with which of the following nuclei?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebellar syndrome. Phylogenetically, the oldest part of the atrophied structure, i.e. the cerebellum, is archicerebellum/vestibulocerebellum, and it is concerned with the fastigial nucleus (connected to vestibular nuclei via descending pathways along with medullary/pontine reticular formations).

The cerebellum is phylogenetically divided into three parts:

Explanation of Other Options:

Globose nucleus (Option B): Part of the paleocerebellum; involved in proximal limb movements, not the oldest part.

Emboliform nucleus (Option C): Also part of paleocerebellum; medial to dentate, not associated with balance.

Dentate nucleus (Option D): Belongs to the neocerebellum (newest part); involved in planning and coordination of voluntary movements.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with ataxia-telangiectasia. Which of the following is an excitatory cell lost in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ataxia-telangiectasia is associated with cerebellar degeneration, particularly involving Purkinje and granule cells. Among these, granule cells (marked as B) are the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex.

  • Granule cells are excitatory interneurons that receive input from mossy fibres and send parallel fibres to Purkinje cells.
  • They use glutamate as a neurotransmitter, and their degeneration contributes to motor incoordination seen in ataxia.
  • Although Purkinje cells are also lost, they are inhibitory, and hence not the correct answer when asked about excitatory neurons.

Explanation of Other Options:

A (Option B): Mossy fibre terminal; Afferent fibre ending; not a cerebellar cortical cell; excites granule cells but is not lost in ataxia-telangiectasia.

D (Option C): Purkinje cell; Inhibitory output neuron of cerebellar cortex using GABA; also degenerated but not excitatory.

C (Option D): Golgi cell; Inhibitory interneuron in the granular layer; regulates granule cell activity.

questions.text: A man presented with tremors caused due to progressive degeneration of the cells that form the output of the cerebellar cortex. Which of the following cells are affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The tremors are caused due to progressive degeneration of the Purkinje cells that form the output of the cerebellar cortex. They form the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

The output of the whole cerebellum is from the deep cerebellar nuclei, namely fastigial, globose, emboliform and dentate.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does the cell pointed to in the arrow inhibit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cell marked by the arrow is a Purkinje cell, the only output neuron of the cerebellar cortex. These GABAergic neurons exert inhibitory control on the deep cerebellar nuclei, such as the dentate, emboliform, globose, and fastigial nuclei. This inhibition is crucial for fine-tuning and coordination of motor activity.

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibres and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibres, giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contains flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells pass through the granular layer into the white matter and synapse with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as the Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibres. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells, and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibres. These parallel fibres form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex.
  • Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibres and mossy fibres. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Explanation of Other Options:

Vestibular nuclei (Option A): Indirectly connected; only the flocculonodular lobe projects directly to them.

Anterior horn of spinal (Option B): These receive input from cerebellar output via descending tracts, not directly from Purkinje cells.

Basal ganglia (Option D): No direct connection with Purkinje cells; they are part of a separate motor circuit.

questions.text: As a researcher studying the circuitry of the cerebellum, which of the following nuclei should you lesion to specifically disrupt the flocculonodular lobe circuitry involved in balance and eye movements?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fastigial nucleus is the deep cerebellar nucleus primarily associated with the flocculonodular lobe, which governs balance and eye movements through its projections to the vestibular nuclei.

  • The flocculo-nodular lobe circuitry of the cerebellum is primarily involved in coordinating eye movements and balance.
  • The Purkinje cells of the flocculonodular lobe project to the fastigial nucleus.
  • The fastigial nucleus lies medially in the vermis and projects efferent fibres to the vestibular and reticular nuclei via the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
  • Lesioning this nucleus would disrupt the vestibulocerebellar pathway, impairing equilibrium and gaze stabilisation.
  • The Fastigial nucleus is responsible for receiving input from the flocculo-nodular lobe and sending output to the vestibular nuclei, which are important for balance control. Therefore, lesioning the Fastigial nucleus would specifically target the circuitry related to the flocculo-nodular lobe.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dentate nucleus (Option B): It is the largest and most lateral cerebellar nucleus and is primarily involved with the lateral cerebellar hemisphere, influencing motor planning via the cerebrocerebellar loop. It does not receive projections from the flocculonodular lobe.

Clarke's nucleus (Option C): This is a spinal cord nucleus (located in lamina VII, T1-L2), involved in the dorsal spinocerebellar tract relaying unconscious proprioception from the lower limb-not part of cerebellar deep nuclei.

Spinal border cells (Option D): These are spinal interneurons contributing to the ventral spinocerebellar tract, transmitting lower limb movement-related signals to the cerebellum, but are not part of the cerebellar circuitry intrinsic to the flocculonodular lobe.

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule

questions.text: Your 27-year-old patient displays ataxia when asked to walk across the examination room. You ask him to stand still with his eyes closed and note marked swaying back and forth. When he opens his eyes, the swaying persists. Vibration sense is normal on all four limbs. Given this clinical picture, such ataxia is likely due to damage to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ataxia that persists even with eyes open, along with normal vibration sense, indicates a lesion in the cerebellum, which is responsible for the coordination of voluntary movements, balance, and posture.

Romberg Test Interpretation:

  • Positive Romberg test: Patient loses balance with eyes closed → suggests sensory ataxia.
  • Romberg sign negative (falls even with eyes open): Suggests cerebellar ataxia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dorsal columns (Option A): Involved in transmitting fine touch, proprioception, and vibration sense. Lesions here cause sensory (spinal) ataxia, where sway increases with eyes closed (positive Romberg). However, in this case, sway persists even with eyes open, and vibration sense is intact, making dorsal column involvement unlikely.

Cerebral peduncles (Option B): Contain descending corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts. Lesions here result in contralateral motor weakness, not ataxia. They are not primarily involved in balance or coordination, which are cerebellar functions.

Posterior limb of the internal capsule (Option C): Contains descending motor fibres. Lesions here cause dense contralateral hemiparesis, possibly with sensory loss depending on involvement of thalamocortical fibres. Does not present with isolated ataxia or postural sway.

choices.text: Ventral anterior nucleus of the thalamus (VA) - superior cerebellar peduncle
Ventral anterior nucleus of the thalamus (VA) - middle cerebellar peduncle
Ventral lateral nucleus of the thalamus (VL) - superior cerebellar peduncle
Ventral lateral nucleus of the thalamus (VL) - middle cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: Efferent axons from the dentate nucleus terminate in what thalamic nucleus and travel through what peduncle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Efferent fibres from the dentate nucleus, the largest and most lateral of the cerebellar nuclei, exit via the superior cerebellar peduncle and terminate primarily in the ventral lateral (VL) nucleus of the thalamus. These projections are crucial for relaying cerebellar output to motor and premotor areas of the cerebral cortex.

  • The dentate nucleus gives rise to cerebellothalamic fibres, which are part of the dentatothalamic tract.
  • These fibres decussate in the midbrain at the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle and ascend to the contralateral VL thalamic nucleus, which then projects to motor cortex areas.
  • This pathway is essential for the coordination and planning of voluntary motor activity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ventral anterior nucleus - SCP (Option A): The VA nucleus receives basal ganglia inputs, not the primary relay for cerebellar efferents.

Ventral anterior nucleus - MCP (Option B): Incorrect thalamic nucleus and wrong peduncle; MCP is afferent (from pontine nuclei).

Ventral lateral nucleus - MCP (Option D): Correct nucleus, but MCP is an afferent peduncle, not used for dentate efferents.

questions.text: As a researcher studying the circuitry of the cerebellum, which of the following cells is known to be the major output neuron of the cerebellar cortex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Purkinje cells are the major output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

  • They receive inputs from various sources within the cerebellum and send their axons to different targets outside the cerebellum.
  • These cells play a crucial role in motor coordination and learning.
  • They are characterised by their distinctive morphology, with a large, flat dendritic tree that receives inputs from parallel fibres and a single axon that projects to the deep cerebellar nuclei.
  • Purkinje cells are critical for the integration and modulation of motor signals, making them the major output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dentate nucleus (Option B): A deep cerebellar nucleus that receives inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and gives excitatory output via the superior cerebellar peduncle.

Fastigial nucleus (Option C): Another deep cerebellar nucleus involved in posture and equilibrium; not part of the cortex.

Clarke's nucleus (Option D): Located in the spinal cord (T1-L2); source of the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, not part of cerebellar cortex or its output.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: Which of the following ascending pathways enters the cerebellum through the peduncle marked in the picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The peduncle marked in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle, which transmits the anterior spinocerebellar tract, an afferent pathway that conveys information from the lower limb proprioceptors.

  • The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle and crosses twice-once in the spinal cord and once again within the cerebellum. Ultimately, it projects ipsilaterally.
  • This tract carries input from muscle spindles, tendon organs, and joint receptors of the lower limb and trunk.
  • This is in contrast to the dorsal spinocerebellar and cuneocerebellar tracts, which enter via the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and the pontocerebellar fibres, which enter via the middle cerebellar peduncle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dorsal spinocerebellar tract (Option A): Enters via the inferior cerebellar peduncle; carries unconscious proprioceptive information from the lower limbs.

Cuneo cerebellar tract (Option B): Also enters via the inferior cerebellar peduncle; transmits proprioception from upper limbs.

Ponto cerebellar fibres (Option D): Enter via the middle cerebellar peduncle; they are corticopontocerebellar fibres relaying input from the contralateral cerebral cortex.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: Fibres from the highlighted structure terminate at which of the following (marked '?')?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The superior cerebellar peduncle includes fibres from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus. It also contains the ventral spinocerebellar tract fibres.

  • The superior cerebellar peduncle contains all the efferent fibres from the dentate, emboliform, and the globose nuclei, and a small fascicle from the fastigial nucleus.
  • Its fibres decussate in the caudal mesencephalon and are destined to synapse in the contralateral red nucleus and thalamus.
  • The middle cerebellar peduncle contains only afferent fibres from the contralateral pontine nuclei.
  • The inferior cerebellar peduncle is a mixture of afferent fibres from the brainstem and spinal cord and efferent fibres to the vestibular nuclei.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fastigial nucleus (Option A): It is the origin of some efferents via the inferior cerebellar peduncle, not the target of superior peduncle fibres.

Inferior olivary nucleus (Option B): It sends climbing fibres to the cerebellum via the inferior cerebellar peduncle (afferent), not a target of superior peduncle efferents.

Subthalamus (Option D): It is not a known destination of cerebellar efferents through the superior cerebellar peduncle.

choices.text: Climbing and mossy fibres are inhibitory and use GABA as the neurotransmitter
Mossy fibres end by forming a synapse with the dendrites of Purkinje cells
All climbing fibres originate from the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus
Efferent fibres from all the cerebellar nuclei leave the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: A patient recovering from COVID-19 presented with a sudden onset of slurred speech and difficulty walking. On examination, cerebellar signs are positive. What is true about the affected circuitry?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute viral cerebellitis secondary to COVID-19.

  • Climbing fibres arise exclusively from the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus and ascend through the layers of the cerebellar cortex to make synapses directly with Purkinje cell dendrites.
  • These fibres are excitatory, using glutamate, not GABA.
  • They form a key afferent input pathway and play an essential role in error correction and motor learning.

Explanation of Other Options:

Climbing and mossy fibres are inhibitory and use GABA as the neurotransmitter (Option A): Incorrect; both are excitatory and use glutamate.

Mossy fibres end by forming a synapse with dendrites of Purkinje cells (Option B): Incorrect; mossy fibres synapse on granule cells, which then activate Purkinje cells via parallel fibres.

Efferent fibres from all the cerebellar nuclei leave the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle (Option D): Incorrect; most efferents, particularly from the dentate and interposed nuclei, exit via the superior cerebellar peduncle, but some efferents from the fastigial nucleus also go through the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

questions.text: A patient with an acoustic neuroma presented with ataxia. MRI brain revealed the tumour impinging on the middle cerebellar peduncle. What fibres are transmitted from this structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The middle cerebellar peduncle carries fibres of the pontocerebellar tract, which conveys input from the contralateral cerebral cortex (via the pontine nuclei) to the cerebellum and is involved in planning and coordination of movement.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tectospinal pathway (Option B): Descends from the superior colliculus to the cervical spinal cord; not part of the cerebellar peduncles.

Spinocerebellar pathway (Option C): Mostly transmitted through the inferior and superior cerebellar peduncles.

Olivocerebellar pathway (Option D): Arises from the inferior olivary nucleus and passes through the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with the condition shown below, and it involves the inferior cerebellar peduncle. All of the following tracts may be involved by the tumour except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is Glioblastoma multiforme, and the anterior spinocerebellar tract does not pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle. It enters the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle.

  • Glioblastoma multiforme is the most malignant and frequently occurring type of primary astrocytoma. It has the worst long-term prognosis (median survival of roughly 1 year).

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior spinocerebellar (Option A): Ascends uncrossed to the cerebellum via the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

Cuneocerebellar (Option C): Carries proprioception from the upper limb, enters through the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

Olivocerebellar (Option D): Originates from the inferior olivary nucleus and travels via the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
